captions.text:
Winter is unquestionably the best season - for
skiing. And for full moons.

We're lucky enough to have winters because
the earth's plane of rotation is tilted relative

to its orbit. This means that when part of
the earth is tilted towards the sun, the sun

stays in the sky for a longer amount of time
each day, and it's warm out. Summer! Of course,

when that part of the earth is tilted away
from the sun, the sun is lower in the sky

and doesn't stay up as long. This might make
winter darker, but you can think of it as

bonus time pointing towards interstellar space!
And, as I said before, winter has the best
full moons.

The moon is new when it's on the same side
of the earth as the sun, and it doesn't reflect

any light on us. This also means the new moon
generally mirrors the sun on its journey across

the sky - it more or less rises and sets with
the sun and follows a similar path. On the

other hand, the moon is full when it's on
the opposite side of the earth from the sun,

its whole face reflecting the sun's light
back at us.

Because of this opposite position, a full
moon is only ever up at night, rising at sunset

and setting at sunrise, and it consequently
also behaves the way the sun does in the opposite

season. When a part of the earth is tilted
towards the full moon, it's tilted away from

the sun - and vice versa. So a summer full
moon is like a winter sun - only appearing

for a few hours and staying close to the horizon.
But a winter full moon is like a summer sun

- it's up for a long time and takes a high
path through the sky. In the darkest months,

the moon, at least when it's full, gives us
long, beautifully lit nights. Combined with

a quiet blanket of snow and the shimmering
aurora, how can you not love winter?

title: Why The Full Moon is Better in Winter

sound like I'm preaching some SJW crap, but humans only like temperature on 
a spectrum. Too hot and too cold are both cons, while mild heat and mild 
cold are pros since they are more comfortable to us.Oh and naked people 
should be a pro ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

comments.text:
That is the Aurora Borealis, The light is created when charged particles 
from the sun follow the earths magnetic field then enter our atmosphere. 
Creating a colorful plasma that dances in the sky.

comments.text:
Are you living in the Southern Hemisphere? When watching the sun rise and 
set, it goes from right to left there, the way it does in this cartoon. 
Where I live, in the Northern Hemisphere, the sun goes from left to right.﻿
comments.author: MountainHawkPYL

comments.text:
+Clayton Carson When you want to take a time-lapse video of the sun 
traveling through the sky in the northern hemisphere, the camera must face 
south, therefore east is on the left, and will travel from left to right to 
the west. In the southern hemisphere, the camera must face north, and the 
east is on the right, and the sun moves from right to left to the west, as 
in this video here.
comments.author: MountainHawkPYL

comments.text:
Right & left are completely subjective & dependent on the direction you're 
facing.  It's much better to simply say the sun rises in the East & sets in 
the West, because it does that no matter what hemisphere you're on.
